item.description: Neandertals, our closest evolutionary relative, lived in parts of Europe and western Asia before disappearing 30,000 years ago. The great questions have always been, did they interbreed with our Homo sapiens ancestors and is there evidence of Neandertal genes in present-day humans? David Reich, Associate Professor of Genetics at Harvard, will address these issues with comparisons of the Neandertal genome to the genomes of present-day humans. Free and open to the public, Geological Lecture Hall
item.name: Neandertals and Modern Humans: The Genetic Evidence for Interbreeding
